results.title: Adolescence
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It's About Time for SBS Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
A lighthearted exploration of the confusion and uncertainties surrounding adolescence through the eyes of 16 year olds from diverse backgrounds. Introduces the characters Tube, Gull, Curtis, Joey, Rosetta, Angela, Pepper and Gloria. Vignettes address “finding yourself, liking yourself and being your own person”, independence vs. limitations, the “real me”, friendships, peer group pressure and the physical/emotional changes occuring during the early teenage years. Similarly, the pressure of uncertain job prospects, school stresses, youthful dreams and concern for the world’s future.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It’s About Time for SBS Television

results.title: Work
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This episode of the innovative SBS television series features young people’s attitude to employment, including the trials of applications and job interviews.

results.title: Sexuality
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This episode deals with teenage hetero-sexual behaviour and aims to show the confusion teenagers experience in dealing with their sexuality. Through a series of comic sketches, teenagers discuss what parents and society tell them about sex, their sex roles as females and males, self-esteem and body image. There is little information in the program as it is more of an attempt to validate adolescent experiences rather than providing any answers.

results.title: Dating
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
Examines dating and focuses on the “first date” for teenagers. Looks at dating from the point of view of girls and boys, and first date etiquette. Also examines how other cultures see their children in relation to dating.

results.title: Teenage blues
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
An episode on boredom, boredom and more boredom. Teenagers, in a set of comic sketches, explore the “nowhere to go, nothing to do syndrome”. Once they take up the challenge of organising the school social, they realise that a creative and positive approach to overcoming boredom can solve the problem.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and It’s About Time

results.title: Food
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
A light hearted look at food by a group of “hungry” teenagers. Diets, fads, junk food addiction are discussed in a series of comic sketches and original songs. Information about nutrition and healthy lifestyle eating in a palatable format for adolescents.

results.title: School
results.creator_credit: Garry Dunstan, Pat Hunder and It's About Time
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Not suitable for adults”.
This anarchic series of comic sketches and songs expresses teenage views on school and teachers. School is seen as a meaningless prison where the students are given no space or time to explore and create.

results.title: Nightmare: the birth of horror
results.brief_description: The Victorian era saw the proliferation of the creation of horror stories that have permeated mass culture in the 21st Century. This series, written, presented and researched by Professor Christopher Frayling, recounts the origins of classic horror novels such as “Frankenstein”, “Dracula” and “The Hounds of the Baskerville”.
results.description: The Victorian era saw the proliferation of the creation of horror stories that have permeated mass culture in the 21st Century. group_works.title: Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde = Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde

results.title: Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde = Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Nightmare: the birth of horror”.
As legend would have it, Robert Louis Stevenson would awake from a nightmare one night in 1885 inspired to write “Dr Jekyll & Mr Hyde,” a tale that many critics have viewed at various times as an aberration to an otherwise successful literary career of writing adventure stories. It wasn’t the first of his nightmares though, as this informative documentary traces RLS’s childhood in Edinburgh, Scotland, which was fraught with his own medical problems, absent parents, and a very close relationship with his religious zealot Nanny. It was a time permeated by nightmares. Researched, written and presented by Professor Christopher Frayling, this episode in “Nightmare: the birth of horror” series focuses on the inspiration behind Stevenson’s tale of a divided self with a heart of darkness, its questionable sexuality, the influence of Jack the Ripper and deviance from the original work, and the impact that fans and family - in particular his wife who oversaw his authorised biography - have had on influencing the cult of Robert Louis Stevenson that is perpetuated today.
